turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What do I think?  I don't want my answer to be influenced by what I want, so I'm going to have to say I don't know.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Yes.  I do not know, either.  What do you want, George?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I want money.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Yes.  Money.  Which is what, George?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Freedom.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Power?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, maybe.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Family.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Beautiful girls?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Keep them coming.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Keep them coming?  Ah, yes.  Ha ha.  You are right.  But money.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Money.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: And Diego?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Diego is my brother.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: George, you look terrible.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, well...

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Diego?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Please.  Sit down.  We'll drink some scotch.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I didn't come here to drink scotch.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: I see.  I'm sorry about this, George. I'm not happy about this situation. It's bad.  You now know who your Brutus is.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You know why I'm here.  You know what I have to do.  I came here for permission. Out of respect, Pablo.  This is bullshit, he's making me look like a punk.

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: It is very difficult.  Diego makes me a lot of money.  If Diego goes so does the money.  You were an excellent teacher, George.  When the student has learned well, the teacher is no longer necessary.  We must remember we have wives, friends, familia.  Even familia that has not been born.  But sometimes, we must forget as well.  I am like you. I must teach the lesson.  We want to teach the lesson.  But we cannot.  We must remember that life is the teacher.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You're saying life will take care of Diego?

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Life will take care of everybody. Diego, me, you.  It is the teacher.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I get it.   I'm really pissed, Pablo. You know the DEA knows about Norman's Cay.  For Chrissakes, Diego worships Adolf Hitler and John Lennon, that's fucked up!

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: I'm sorry, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, well, what are you gonna do?  You and me, Pablo?  Are we good?

turns.speaker: ESCOBAR
turns.text: Of course, George.  We are beautiful. We are brothers.  Real brothers.  Not like Diego.  We started this, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: There's something out there for me, Dad. Something different.  Something free form, you know?  Something for me, and college just isn't it.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: That's too bad.  You would have been the first one in the family.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Alright.  You want me to get your old job back?  Because I could, you know, I could put in that word.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, Dad.  I don't want to...I mean, I just don't want...

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm going to California.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: There's something out there for me, Dad. Something different.  Something free form, you know?  Something for me, and college just isn't it.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: That's too bad.  You would have been the first one in the family.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Alright.  You want me to get your old job back?  Because I could, you know, I could put in that word.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, Dad.  I don't want to...I mean, I just don't want...

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm going to California.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: May the wind always be at your back and the sun always upon your face...

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: ...and the winds of destiny carry you aloft...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Just low.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: You loved her, didn't you?  You really loved her.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, Dad.  I really did.  What am I gonna do?

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Tough spot.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You mad at me?

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Not mad.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, you are.  I can tell by the way you look at me.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: I just don't know what you're thinking. I don't understand your choices.  You know, the police are looking for you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I know.  I'm great at what I do, Dad.  I mean, I'm really great.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Let me tell you something, son.  You would have been great at anything.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: So, business is going good.  I've got this import/export thing going on in Miami that's been very profitable.  With my investments...

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Don't bullshit me, George.  I don't see you very much, I don't want to waste the time.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: You're like your mother.  You love money.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Dad.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: No, it's good.  You have a family.  It's good if it makes you happy.  It's nice to have nice things.  Are you happy, son?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, Dad.  I'm happy right now.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: I heard.  Ermine, your son is here.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: She's angry.  It's all over the news.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah.  Listen.  I'm going to be going away for awhile.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: You're not going to trial?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Give this to Mom, will you?

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Money.  You and your mother.  All the time chasing it.  I never understood it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Give it to her, Dad.  It'll make her happy.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Yeah, I know.  This is it, isn't it?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Tell Mom, you know...

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: I'll tell her.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: And that FBI agent, Trout?  When he had to get on his knees to put my boots on? You said...

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: That's where you belong...

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: ...you sonofabitch.  Putting on George's boots.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: That was a good one, Dad.  That was really something.  Remember that?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I guess I kind of lost sight of things. "May the wind always be at your back and the sun always upon your face, and the winds of destiny carry you aloft to dance with the stars."  Love, George.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: That was a beautiful message.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I meant every word of it.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Did you know I died two weeks after you sent me that tape?

turns.speaker: GARCIA
turns.text: How are you doing, George?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What do you guys want?

turns.speaker: GARCIA
turns.text: You hear about your old friend, Diego?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What about him?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What the fuck?  Is he going to walk?

turns.speaker: GARCIA
turns.text: He's going down, George.  It's election year.  We're not making any deals.

turns.speaker: GARCIA
turns.text: Don't be stupid, George.  We've got him. We've got him dead to rights.  But like I said, this is top priority so we're handing out free passes on this one. And the first one's got your name on it. Cut your sentence in half, maybe more.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No thanks, fellas.  You've got the wrong fucking guy.  I'm not a rat.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: Figured it out.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Figured what out?

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: You know how we were wondering what we were going to do for money?  Being how we don't want to get jobs and whatnot? Well, check this out.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It's oregano.  You got ripped off, pal. What are you gonna do with all this?

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: We sell it.  I got it all figured out. We make three finger lids and sell them on the beach.  We move all of it.  We've made ourselves a hundred bucks.  Or a lot of weed for our head.  What do you think?  Not bad, huh?  I got the baggies and everything.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: George.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: Tuna.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: Figured it out.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Figured what out?

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: You know how we were wondering what we were going to do for money?  Being how we don't want to get jobs and whatnot? Well, check this out.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It's oregano.  You got ripped off, pal. What are you gonna do with all this?

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: We sell it.  I got it all figured out. We make three finger lids and sell them on the beach.  We move all of it.  We've made ourselves a hundred bucks.  Or a lot of weed for our head.  What do you think?  Not bad, huh?  I got the baggies and everything.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: George.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: Tuna.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: Look what the cat dragged in.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Holy shit, Dulli.  What the hell are you doing here?

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: What the fuck are you talking about, man?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: The set-up is wrong.  We're doing all the legwork, and at the end of the day, we're still paying retail.  We're getting middled.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: Source?  What about Derek?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: He's getting middled, too.  And Derek's our partner.  What's good for us is good for him.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Do I know you?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Why are you smiling?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Why are you smiling?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't know.  My name is George.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: I know who you are, El Americano. Mister George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What is your name?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: You better know what you're doing, George.  You're playing with fire.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I like fire.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Jesus Christ.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Oh, don't be such a fucking hypocrite. I quit smoking, didn't I?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Put that shit away, they're here.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: George.  Oh, Jesus Christ, George.  Look at you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Shhh, honey, never mind.  It's alright. It's over.  I quit the business.  I'm out.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Pablo said no?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Pablo said no.  It's all over.  And I'm never going back.  I have you.  We have the baby.  And there's nothing else. It's just the family now.  Shhh.  Sleep now.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Look, Mirtha.  She's walking.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: She did that before.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No.  These are her first steps.  Watch her.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Yeah.  I know.  She did that before.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: But this is...

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: I said, I've seen it before.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Alright.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Can you lift the furnace.  I need money.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Out.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, that's alright.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Oh fucking relax.  Let your hair down for once.  It's your fucking birthday, for Chrissakes.  You're such a fucking pussy.  I swear to G-d, I married this big time drug dealer and wound up with the maid.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: What are we going to do?!  What are we going to use for money?!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Please, Mirtha.  I'll start working for Augusto.  I'll talk to him tonight. I'll do something.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Don't touch me.  Tell me.  Just answer the question.  What do I spend?  What? How will we live?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Not in front of the kid.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Don't give me that shit.  You just better do something.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: There's a fucking cop behind us, Mirtha. Be cool, will ya.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Fuck you, George, just fucking drive.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Hey, why don't you just put a "I'm doing cocaine" sign on the car.  What is your fucking problem?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: My problem?  We're broke, that's my fucking problem.  And you're a fucking spy.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: That's right.  Always spying, always judging.  Everyone's laughing at you, you fucking pussy.  You let Diego fuck you in the ass.  Maybe you are a fucking faggot.  You must be fucking Diego because you're not fucking me.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: You should have taken better care of me, you know?  You've been away a long time. Four years.  Say something.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What do you want me to say?  I'm in prison.  You should know.  You put me here.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Fuck you, George.  I knew you'd say something like that.  Always thinking about yourself.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You knew I was seeing Kristina, right?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Yeah.  She told me.  You walk her to school.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, so I've been thinking.  I love her, y'know?  I kind of want to have her.  I've been away for so long.  Make up for the missed time, you know?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: I haven't seen one dollar from you.  You haven't paid me one cent in child support, alimony.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, well.  I'm working on that.  I've got something going.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Yeah?  I better see some money out of it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, you will.  Of course.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Hey, look.  You start paying, who knows what will happen.  You're a good father, George.  I always gave you that.  But you've got to talk to her.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: She's getting big.  Getting her own ideas.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I know.  Well, that's all I really wanted to say.  So, okay, then.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Hey, George.  You okay?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah.  I'm fine.  I'm good.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mirtha, what's going on?  Everything okay with Kristina?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Kristina's fine.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Is she here?  Is she coming?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Is she here?  George, Kristina hates you.  You fucked her over one too many times.  And I'm not here to socialize. Did you hear about Diego?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Well, I got a call from Pablo.  He said this thing with Diego is a disaster. He's giving up lab locations, names, bank accounts, he was very pissed off. Pablo said to take him down.  His exact words were "Fuck Diego."

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: He wants me to testify?  Is that what he's asking me to do?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: George, he wasn't asking.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Mirtha, how are you doing?

turns.speaker: MIRTHA
turns.text: Better than you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Everything's gonna be okay, sweetheart. Don't be upset.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: What's happening to us?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: Are we gonna split up?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: No, never.  Don't even think about that, it's impossible.  I love your mother. And you are my heart.  Could I live without my heart?  Could I?

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Nothing.  I just wanted you to know I was out.  I just wanted to see you.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: Well, here I am.  See?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: How are you doing?

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: George, you just can't show up, tell me you love me, and have everything be okay.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Dad.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You can call me Dad if you want.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: I don't want, alright?  It's not funny. I'm really pissed off, George.  You blew it, now leave me alone.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Kristina, c'mon, I'm sorry.  I'm going to make this right.  I've got a few things going on...

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: What do you want from me?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Just to walk with you.  I want to be your dad again.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: Do what you want, it's a free country.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Let me ask you something.  If you could go anywhere in the world, anywhere, where would you want to go?

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: You mean, like a trip?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, sure, whatever.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: California?  You can go anywhere in the world.  India.  Tibet.  Australia. Paris.  And you choose California?

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What is it?  A Disneyland thing?

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: No.  I just kind of like the sound of it.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: California, huh?

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: California.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: Bye, Dad.  See you in the morning, okay?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'll be here.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm thinking about getting out of town this week.  You want to come with me?

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't know.  Maybe California.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: You swear?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah.  Go out there, check it out, see what it's like.  I've got some stuff to do this week, but I'm thinking maybe Thursday.  Thursday after school.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: You know I can't.  Mom will never let me go.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You let me take care of your mother. You just pack your bags.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: But I've got school.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: There's schools in California.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: You swear?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: That's right.  Three o'clock.  Thursday. At your mother's.  You and me.  It's a date.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: I don't believe you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I swear.  On my life.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: Swear on my life.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I swear on your life.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I'm sorry, baby.  I'm so sorry.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: It's alright, Dad.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I didn't mean to...

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: I know, Dad.  I know...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I fucked up.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: Shhhh.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I love you.  I love you so much.  You've got to know that.  You've got to know.

turns.speaker: KRISTINA
turns.text: I know, Dad.  I love you too.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: After everything.  After everything, the only thing left out of my whole life is you.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: But I have a visitor.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Not today, George.  Time to go back.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: But I want to put her name on the list for tomorrow.  My daughter.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Okay, George.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Because she's visiting me.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: We'll do that tomorrow, okay?  It's lockdown time.

turns.speaker: PROSECUTOR
turns.text: Mr. Jung, do you know Diego Delgado?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes, I do.

turns.speaker: PROSECUTOR
turns.text: Do you see him here in the courtroom?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes, he's sitting right there at the end of the table.

turns.speaker: PROSECUTOR
turns.text: Let the record state the witness has identified, Diego Delgado.

turns.speaker: PROSECUTOR
turns.text: Mr. Jung, can you describe the circumstances of how you began talking about cocaine with Mr. Delgado?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Shortly after I arrived at Danbury Federal Correctional Institute I related to Diego that the crime I was in for was smuggling marijuana. Diego told me he had high level connections in Colombia and they needed to find someone to help them transport cocaine into America...

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: It's a four-man operation.  Two on the ground.  Two in the air.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Who's the co-pilot?

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: You're looking at him.  We provide the plane, transportation cost, U.S. landing spot, and take it to wherever you want it to go.  You provide the pick up point in South America, and are responsible for payment.  You assume all the bust risks.  We take sixty-five percent of all transportation fees, ten percent of the gross, plus our expenses. This is not a negotiation, so if this is okay with you, we can talk further.  If not, we can forget we had this conversation.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Sounds fine.  I'll need to meet everybody.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: They're over at the booth.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: You saved my life, Dulli.  You'll never fucking know.  All you guys.  Everyone just got a raise.  Instead of ten percent, you get fifteen.

turns.speaker: LEON
turns.text: Jesus, George, fifteen percent.  That's an extra two-hundred large.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't give a shit.  Split it up.  Have a great life.  I'm done.  I'm out. Starting over.  Cheers.

turns.speaker: SANTIAGO
turns.text: Ramon tells me you are looking for some mota.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yes, I am.

turns.speaker: SANTIAGO
turns.text: For instance, something like this?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Very nice.  I'll take it.

turns.speaker: SANTIAGO
turns.text: Ha ha ha.  You are funny.   Really, how much will you be needing?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: All of it.  As much as you've got.  A couples thousand pounds.  I'll be back in a week with a plane.

turns.speaker: SANTIAGO
turns.text: Listen, Americano, it is very nice to meet you, but maybe we are going too fast.  You take a little and then come back.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: I don't need a little.  I need a lot.

turns.speaker: SANTIAGO
turns.text: Marijuana is illegal in my country, and I believe in yours, as well.  We must be careful.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: What if I brought you, let's say, fifty thousand dollars?  Would that eliminate some of your concerns?

turns.speaker: SANTIAGO
turns.text: Amigo, you bring me fifty-thousand dollars, and I have no more concerns.

turns.speaker: SANTIAGO
turns.text: Good to see you, Jorge.  You are a man of your word.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Actually, I've got some news.  That fifty thousand I promised you, I couldn't get it.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Well, I'll tell you.  I was walking down the beach, minding my business, when who did I see but this fucking guy.  I didn't know you guys were living in California.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah, but what are you doing out here?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: I'm on vacation.  On my way back to school.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: This calls for a joint.  You want to do the honors?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: No, man.  I'm too fucked up.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Right on.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: G-d, I'm stoned.  I'm stoned.  I'm really...

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Stoned?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: I wish there was shit like this back home.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Shit, yeah.  Do you know how much money I could make if I had this stuff back east?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: When there's something to move, it's too easy not to.  Do you know how many colleges are in a twenty mile radius? U. Mass, Amherst, B.U....

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: It's not enough.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: So, we need to get to the source.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Okay.  So we need a source.  Where do we start?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Who speaks Spanish?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Not that far, only halfway.  You sure you know what you're doing?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Relax.  I've flown with my old man a million times.  And he always told me, the taking off part is easy, it's the landing you've got to worry about.

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Holy shit, Dulli!

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Georgie, oh man, hold the mayo!

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: That was it.  Seeing Dulli after fourteen years sealed the deal for me. The rest was just details.  My end was roughly five-hundred thousand.  Kristina and I could have a good life for five hundred grand.  Start over somewhere. One final score.  That's all I needed.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Are we good?

turns.speaker: GEORGE
turns.text: Are we good?  Yeah, we're good.  We're beautiful.  We're perfect.  This is A grade, one-hundred percent pure Colombian cocaine, Ladies and Gentlemen. Disco shit.  Pure as the driven snow. Good riddance.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: Nice weed, huh?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Fuck yeah.  I never seen nothing like it.  I'm fucking wasted.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: No shit, Kevin?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: Smith.  Hampshire....

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Right.  And Holyoke.  There are a hundred thousand rich kids with their parents' money to spend, but there's never anything available.  Nothing good, anyway.  I'm paying four hundred dollars for shit.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Twenty, forty, sixty, eighty, nine. Twenty, forty, sixty, eighty, a thousand.  It's all there.  Wow.  A hundred and twenty-eight thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: Jesus Christ, I'm getting a boner just looking at it.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: What's the matter, George?  Something wrong?  You look like you just fucked your mother.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: Cheer up, man.  Half this money is ours. We're fucking rich.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: This is bullshit, George.  We're never going to find anything down there.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: You know, he's got a point.  We're fucking Americans.  We stick out like sore thumbs.

turns.speaker: TUNA
turns.text: I can't believe we're stealing a plane.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Don't be such a pussy.

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: Look around. I've put everything at your disposal. Go take a look with your own eyes.

turns.speaker: 2ND JOURNALIST
turns.text: The strike is a success; but ...

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: No. It has failed in its objective.

turns.speaker: 2ND JOURNALIST
turns.text: But the NLF has always spoken of a strike as a demonstration ...

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: And you believe the NLF?

turns.speaker: 2ND JOURNALIST
turns.text: They seemed to be plausible this time. A general strike is a good argument for the UN.

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: The UN is far away, dear sir. It is easier to make oneself heard with bombs. If I were in their place, I would use bombs.

turns.speaker: 2ND JOURNALIST
turns.text: Colonel Mathieu ... Much has been said lately not only of the successes obtained by the paratroopers, but also of the methods that they have employed ... Can you tell us something about this?

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: The successes obtained are the results of those methods. One presupposes the other and vice versa.

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: It is an inevitable stage in revolutionary war; from terrorism, one passes to insurrection ... as from open guerrilla warfare one passes to real war, the latter being the determining factor ...

turns.speaker: 3RD JOURNALIST
turns.text: Dien Bien Phu?

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: In Indochina, <U>they</U> won.

turns.speaker: 3RD JOURNALIST
turns.text: And here?

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: It depends on you.

turns.speaker: 3RD JOURNALIST
turns.text: Excuse me, colonel. I have the impression that perhaps due to excessive prudence ... my colleagues continue to ask the same allusive questions, to which you can only respond in an allusive manner. I think it would be better to call things by their right names; if one means torture, then one should call it torture.

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: I understand. What's your question?

turns.speaker: 3RD JOURNALIST
turns.text: The questions have already been asked. I would only like some precise answers, that's all ...

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: Let's try to be precise then. The word "torture" does not appear in our orders. We have always spoken of interrogation as the only valid method in a police operation directed against unknown enemies. As for the NLF, they request that their members, in the event of capture, should maintain silence for twenty-four hours, and then, they may talk. Thus, the organization has already had the time necessary to render useless any information furnished ... What type of interrogation should we choose? ... the one the courts use for a crime of homicide which drags on for months?

turns.speaker: 3RD JOURNALIST
turns.text: The law is often inconvenient, colonel ...

turns.speaker: MATHIEU
turns.text: And those who explode bombs in public places, do they perhaps respect the law? When you asked that question to Ben M'Hidi, remember what he said? No, gentlemen, believe me, it is a vicious circle. And we could discuss the problem for hours without reaching any conclusions. Because the problem does not lie here. The problem is: the NLF wants us to leave Algeria and we want to remain. Now, it seems to me that, despite varying shades of opinion, you all agree that we must remain. When the rebellion first began, there were not even shades of opinion. All the newspapers, even the left-wing ones wanted the rebellion suppressed. And we were sent here for this very reason. And we are neither madmen nor sadists, gentlemen. Those who call us fascists today, forget the contribution that many of us made to the Resistance. Those who call us Nazis, do not know that among us there are survivors of Dachau and Buchenwald. We are soldiers and our only duty is to win. Therefore, to be precise, I would now like to ask you a question: Should France remain in Algeria? If you answer "yes," then you must accept all the necessary consequences.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Go ahead! C'mon ... Repeat everything from the beginning, and then we'll let you go. Name ...

turns.speaker: ALGERIAN
turns.text: Sid Ahmed.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Second name.

turns.speaker: ALGERIAN
turns.text: Sail.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Which "district" do you belong to?

turns.speaker: ALGERIAN
turns.text: Second district ...

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Second district ... Explain better ...

turns.speaker: ALGERIAN
turns.text: Second district, Casbah, West Algiers.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: What "group"?

turns.speaker: ALGERIAN
turns.text: Third group.

turns.speaker: SERGEANT
turns.text: Third group. What's your assignment?

turns.speaker: ALGERIAN
turns.text: Uh ... responsible for the sixth section.

turns.speaker: HACENE
turns.text: You afraid of these ...?

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: Don't move, Hacene.

turns.speaker: HACENE
turns.text: Why are you afraid? We've always been friends. One might even say that I brought you up ... Isn't it true, Ali?

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: It's true.

turns.speaker: HACENE
turns.text: What's happened to you?

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: The NLF has condemned you to death.

turns.speaker: HACENE
turns.text: How much are they paying you?

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: They're not paying me anything. They've already warned you twice; this is the last warning. Decide.

turns.speaker: HACENE
turns.text: What ... What must I decide?

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: You've got to change occupations, Hacene. Right away!

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: With an unloaded pistol?

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: I'll explain.

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: Let's suppose you were a spy. In prison, when the NLF contacts you, you pretend to support the revolution, and then the French help you to escape ...

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: Sure. By shooting at me.

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: Even that could be a trick. You escape, then show up at the address which the brothers in prison gave to you, and so you are able to contact me ...

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: I don't even know your name yet ...

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: My name is Kader, Ali ... Saari Kader ... In other words, in order to join the organization, you had to undergo a test. I could have told you to murder the barman, but he's an Algerian ... and the police would let you kill him, even though he is one of theirs. By obeying such an order, you still could have been a double agent. And that's why I told you to kill the French policeman: because the French wouldn't have let you do it. If you were with the police you wouldn't have done it.

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: But I haven't shot him.

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: You weren't able to. But what's important is that you tried.

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: What's important for me is that you let me risk my life for nothing.

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: C'mon ... you're exaggerating. The orders were to shoot him in the back.

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: I don't do that kind of thing.

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: Then don't complain.

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: You still haven't told me why you didn't let me kill him.

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: Because we aren't ready yet for the French. Before attacking, we must have safe places from which to depart and find refuge. Of course, there is the Casbah. But even the Casbah isn't safe yet. There are too many drunks, pushers, whores, addicts, spies ... people who talk too much ... people who are ready to sell themselves, undecided people. We must either convince them or eliminate them. We must think of ourselves first. We must clean out the Casbah first. Only then will we be able to deal with the French. Do you understand, Ali?

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: And how many are we?

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: Not enough.

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: Why? Isn't he sleeping here?

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: No, it's better if he doesn't. The house is filled with new people.

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: It's better to split up, to increase our chances. We must change hiding places, and change them continually ... In the meantime, we must make new contacts, replace our arrested brothers, reorganize our sections--

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: Yes, but we must also show them that we still exist.

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: Of course. As soon as possible.

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: No, immediately. The people are demoralized. Leave this to me ...

turns.speaker: KADER
turns.text: No. Not you, or any one of us. As long as we are free, the NLF continues to exist in the Casbah. If they manage to take us too, there won't be anything left ... And from nothing comes nothing ...

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: Go away!

turns.speaker: PETIT OMAR
turns.text: Men have two faces: one that laughs and one that cries ...

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: Can you read?

turns.speaker: PETIT OMAR
turns.text: Sure ...

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: Read it.

turns.speaker: PETIT OMAR
turns.text: Here?

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: Where's Kader?

turns.speaker: PETIT OMAR
turns.text: With the others. They are trying to stop the people.

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: Go away.

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: Be careful now. Unless you know how it works, it's better if you sit on the plank and move forward like this ...

turns.speaker: BEN M'HIDI
turns.text: Let's try ...

turns.speaker: BEN M'HIDI
turns.text: It's good nobody is following us ...

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: It's a question of habit ...

turns.speaker: BEN M'HIDI
turns.text: What do you think of the strike, Ali?

turns.speaker: ALI
turns.text: I think it'll be a success ...

turns.speaker: BEN M'HIDI
turns.text: Yes, I think so too ... It's been organized well ... But what will the French do?
